{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2016}} {{Expand Romanian|Uniunea Salvați România|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox political party | name = Save Romania Union | native_name = Uniunea Salvați România | native_name_lang = ro | logo = File:USR logo.svg | colorcode = {{Save Romania Union/meta/color}} | abbreviation = USR | leader = [[Dan Barna]] | founder = [[Nicușor Dan]] | founded = 1 July 2015 ([[Save Bucharest Union|USB]])
2016 (USR) | headquarters = Blvd. Aviatorilor 9, [[Bucharest]] | membership_year = | membership = | ideology = [[Political corruption|Anti-corruption]]{{cite web|first=Wolfram|last=Nordsieck|url=http://www.parties-and-elections.eu/romania.html|title=Romania|website=Parties and Elections in Europe|year=2016|accessdate=19 August 2018}}{{cite web|title=Leader of Romanian anti-corruption party resigns|url=https://www.politico.eu/article/leader-of-romanian-anti-corruption-party-resigns/|website=POLITICO|date=1 June 2017|accessdate=13 April 2018}}
[[Pro-Europeanism]]https://www.usr.ro/programe/romania-in-lume/ | position = [[Big tent]]{{cite web|title=Coaliția pentru Familie, motiv de ceartă în USR|url=https://www.digi24.ro/stiri/actualitate/politica/coalitia-pentru-familie-motiv-de-cearta-in-usr-733793|date=29 May 2017|accessdate=4 May 2018}} | national = | european = | international = | europarl = | colors = [[Blue]] | slogan = | seats1_title = [[Chamber of Deputies (Romania)|Chamber of Deputies]] | seats1 = {{Composition bar|28|357|hex={{Save Romania Union/meta/color}}}} | seats2_title = [[Senate of Romania|Senate]] | seats2 = {{Composition bar|13|157|hex={{Save Romania Union/meta/color}}}} | seats3_title = [[European Parliament]] | seats3 = {{Composition bar|0|32|hex={{Save Romania Union/meta/color}}}} | seats4_title = Mayors | seats4 = {{Composition bar|0|3186|hex={{Save Romania Union/meta/color}}}} | seats5_title = [[Counties of Romania|County]] Councilors | seats5 = {{Composition bar|0|1434|hex={{Save Romania Union/meta/color}}}} | seats6_title = Local Councilors | seats6 = {{Composition bar|54|40067|hex={{Save Romania Union/meta/color}}}} | website = {{URL|http://www.usr.ro}} | country = Romania }} The '''Save Romania Union''' ({{lang-ro|Uniunea Salvați România}}, USR) is a [[list of political parties in Romania|political party in Romania]]. The party was founded following the success of the [[Save Bucharest Union]] (USB) party in the [[Romanian local elections, 2016|2016 local elections]]. After being officially registered as a political party in 2016, it united with the local USB and Union for Codlea parties, thus gaining most of its initial membership base from the two latter parties.{{cite web|url=http://www.hotnews.ro/stiri-politic-21238686-usb-usr-uniunea-pentru-codlea-fuzioneaza-duminica-intr-eveniment-usile-inchise.htm|title=USB, USR si Uniunea pentru Codlea au fuzionat duminica intr-un eveniment cu usile inchise|language=ro-RO|access-date=2016-10-05}} It is currently the third largest political party in the [[Parliament of Romania|Romanian Parliament]] after the [[Romanian legislative election, 2016|2016 legislative elections]] and runs on an anti-corruption platform.https://www.euractiv.com/section/elections/interview/dan-barna-save-romania-union-similar-to-macrons-en-marche/ ==Ideology and issues== [[Dan Barna]], the leader of USR, characterized the party as "generally centre-right", leaning centre-right on economic policy and centrist in terms of social policy. However, USR has a substantial amount of both progressive and conservative members.{{Cite news|url=https://stirileprotv.ro/stiri/politic/nicusor-dan-usr-are-doua-probleme-conflictul-dintre-progresisti-si-conservatori-si-lipsa-de-colegialitate-si-de-incredere.html|title=Nicusor Dan: USR are doua probleme: conflictul dintre progresisti si conservatori si lipsa de colegialitate si de incredere|work=Stirileprotv.ro|access-date=2018-05-04}} He compared the party with [[Emmanuel Macron]]'s [[La République En Marche!]], while mentioning that the key difference between the two is that USR predominantly consists of people who have not been involved in politics before. === Anti-corruption campaign === Since its foundation USR has supported the [[Corruption in Romania#Anti-corruption measures|anti-corruption drive in Romania]] and the activity of the [[National Anticorruption Directorate]]. USR was against the modifications to the justice laws initiated by the government coalition [[Social Democratic Party (Romania)|PSD]]-[[Alliance of Liberals and Democrats (Romania)|ALDE]] and requested the rejection of OUG 13 (''see also the [[2017–2018 Romanian protests]]''). In 2018 USR helped and supported the initiators of ''Fără Penali în Funcții Publice'' ("No Convicts in Public Office") civic campaign, whose objective is to bar the persons convicted to final imprisonment sentences for [[Mens rea|intentional offences]] from being elected to [[local government]], the [[Chamber of Deputies (Romania)|Chamber of Deputies]], the [[Senate of Romania|Senate]] or the office of [[President of Romania]] by amending the Article 37 of the [[Constitution of Romania|Romanian Constitution]]{{cite web|url=https://farapenaliinfunctiipublice.ro/|title=Fără Penali în Funcții Publice ("No Convicts in Public Office")|language=Romanian|accessdate=5 October 2018}} (which regulates the [[nomination rules]]). USR and volunteers collected more than 1{{nbsp}}million signatures from eligible voters.{{cite news|url=https://www.digi24.ro/stiri/actualitate/politica/usr-initiativa-cetateneasca-fara-penali-in-functii-publice-a-strans-peste-1-000-000-de-semnaturi-984347|title=USR: Iniţiativa cetăţenească "Fără penali în funcţii publice" a strâns peste 1.000.000 de semnături ("USR: The Civic Initiative 'No Convicts in Public Office' Collected Over 1 Million Signatures")|date=21 August 2018|accessdate=5 October 2018|language=Romanian}} === LGBT rights === USR's position on [[LGBT rights in Romania|LGBT issues]] is not clearly defined. The party leader, [[Dan Barna]], declared: "Gay marriage is not yet a subject for the public agenda, there is no initiative promoting same-sex marriage. Maybe in 20, 30 years next generations will take care of this problem, but for now, this is not a priority." However, USR was the only parliamentary party in Romania that did not support the [[Romanian constitutional referendum, 2018|constitutional referendum]], proposed by [[Coaliția pentru Familie]] (CpF) and supported by the [[Romanian Orthodox Church]]. The constitutional amendment proposed to change the definition of family in order to prohibit the [[same-sex marriage]], however it failed, as the turnout was only 21.1%,[http://referendum2018.bec.ro/wp-content/uploads/2018/10/prezenta_16.01.pdf Referendumul naţional pentru revizuirea Constituţiei din 6 și 7 octombrie 2018] below the required voter turnout threshold of 30%.{{cite web |title=Prezența vot |url=http://prezenta.bec.ro/ |website=Biroul Electoral Central |accessdate=7 October 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-romania-referendum/romanian-constitutional-ban-on-same-sex-marriage-fails-on-low-vote-turnout-idUSKCN1MH0XI?il=0|title=Romanian constitutional ban on same sex marriage fails on low vote turnout|work=Reuters|date=7 October 2018}} USR considered the referendum a way to divide the Romanian people and to distract the attention from the real issues Romania currently faces, such as corruption.{{cite news|url=http://www.ziare.com/referendum-constitutie-familie/vot/usr-indeamna-oamenii-sa-boicoteze-referendumul-pentru-familie-1530170|title=USR indeamna alegatorii sa boicoteze referendumul pentru familie ("USR Urges the Voters to Boycott the Family Referendum")|date=18 September 2018|accessdate=5 October 2018|language=Romanian}} === Roșia Montană === USR supported the inclusion of the [[Roșia Montană|Roşia Montană]] site in UNESCO World Heritage. At the 42nd session of the [[World Heritage site|UNESCO World Heritage]] Committee, held in [[Manama]], [[Bahrain]], the government's representative, Ştefan Răzvan Rab, state secretary of the Ministry of Culture, in [[Bahrain]], on June 24 to July 4, asked for postponement on behalf of Romania including the Rosia Montana Mining Cultural Landscape in the World Heritage List until the completion of the judicial dispute with [[Gabriel Resources]], an unprecedented fact in the history of [[UNESCO]]. USR Senator [[Vlad Alexandrescu]], under whose Ministry of Culture 2015-2016 Roşia Montană was included in the UNESCO indicative list, accused the PSD-ALDE government coalition of treason, writing in a post on 2 July 2018 on Facebook: "It is Romania's most shameful moment since being a member of UNESCO. All the other states of the world carry a fierce negotiation these days so that their monuments are included in the UNESCO list, and each success is welcomed with cheers and cheers. In contrast to the civilized world is Romania. The only state that has campaigned for its monument not to be on this list. A state seized by a bunch of villains who do not give a damn about the importance of heritage. All they want is to leave UNESCO in peace with their ideas, to make a crater over Roşia Montană so that they can fill their pockets. Of course, the rest of the states know this, not everyone is as "professional" as our government. And so we will be known from now on, those who sell their patrimony for the welfare of their politicians. What you have done here, members and representatives of the Government, is treason. You have acted so that our patrimony is reduced to a crater in the near future. And this will not be without consequences, I promise you! " === European affiliation === USR supports [[Romania]]'s membership of the [[European Union]] and is in favor of a joint European external policy and [[Common Security and Defence Policy|military]] and of Romania's accession to the [[Schengen Area]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.usr.ro/programe/romania-in-lume/|title=Arhive România în lume - Uniunea Salvați România|website=Uniunea Salvați România|language=ro-RO|access-date=2018-10-11}} While not being part of a pan-European political party yet, USR has had negotiations with [[Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Party|ALDE]] and to a lesser extent with the [[European People's Party|EPP]] and the [[European Green Party|European Greens]]. USR's hesitation to join [[Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Party|ALDE]] is due to the fact that a Romanian party they vehemently oppose ([[Alliance of Liberals and Democrats (Romania)|ALDE]]) is part of the European party and bears the exact same name.{{Cite news|url=https://www.g4media.ro/ghinea-usr-are-discutii-active-cu-partidul-european-alde.html|title=Ghinea: USR are discuții active cu partidul european ALDE|date=2018-06-15|work=G4Media.ro|access-date=2018-10-11|language=ro-RO}} ==Party leaders== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" width=70% |- ! '''Sports Backers''' is a non-profit organization founded in 1991 and located in Richmond, Virginia at [[Sports Backers Stadium]]. The mission of the Sports Backers has expanded from its beginnings as a traditional sports commission for economic development to be focused on increasing physical activity to improve the health of area residents. The Sports Backers created [http://www.movementmakers.com Movement Makers], a national active living conference to encourage community health organizations that promote physical activity to have a place to gather and learn from each other. The annual event takes place in Richmond, Virginia and occurs at the same time as Dominion Riverrock. The Sports Backers own Dominion Riverrock,<ref>{{cite web|title=Dominion Riverrock Event Organizers|url=http://www.dominionriverrock.com/sponsors/|website=Dominion Riverrock|publisher=Dominion Riverrock|accessdate=27 July 2014}}</ref> the largest outdoor sports and music festival in the country,<ref name=Richmond.com>{{cite web|title=Dominion Riverrock Sees Record Attendance|url=http://www.richmond.com/events/article_4293843e-dee9-11e3-933c-001a4bcf6878.html|website=Richmond.com |accessdate=May 19, 2014}}</ref> the [[Monument Avenue 10K|Ukrop's Monument Avenue 10k]], the 8th largest running race in the United States,<ref name="Running USA">{{cite web|title=Largest Running Races|url=http://www.runningusa.org/largest-races|website=Runningusa.org|accessdate=26 July 2014}}</ref> and the [[Richmond Marathon|Anthem Richmond Marathon]], the 18th largest marathon in the country.<ref name="Running USA 2">{{cite web|title=Largest Marathons in USA|url=http://www.runningusa.org/index.cfm?fuseaction=reports.statistics |website=Runningusa.org|accessdate=26 July 2014}}</ref> The organization owns and produces 15 events. The organization also supports other organizations with more than 24 major sports tourism events in the Richmond region receiving annual support through marketing grants, operational assistance and loaning equipment.<ref name="Sports Backers Website">{{cite web|title=Events Sports Tourism|url=http://www.sportsbackers.org|accessdate=26 July 2014}}</ref> Sports Backers was named the Member of the Year by the [[National Association of Sports Commissions]] in 2006, 2009, 2011 and 2015.<ref name="National Association of Sports Commissions">{{cite web|title=Members of the Year Awards|url=http://sportscommissions.wordpress.com/2011/04/22/nasc-recognizes-outstanding-members-at-2011-nasc-sports-event-symposium/|accessdate=26 July 2014}}</ref> [[wikipedia.org/wiki/Jon Lugbill|Jon Lugbill]] is the organization's executive director and has been leading the organization since 1993.
The Sports Backers training teams provide local residents a way to prepare for local road races.<ref name="Richmond Times-Dispatch">{{cite web|title=Race Director Lisa Randolph|url=http://www.timesdispatch.com/sports/running/monument-ave-10k/sunday-q-a-lisa-randolph-sports-backers-event-director-for/article_6999f995-08e8-52a8-8f13-5b32baa03cd7.html?mode=image&photo=0|work=[[Richmond Times-Dispatch]]|accessdate=26 July 2014}}</ref> The Sports Backers Marathon, Half Marathon and 8k training teams prepared runners for the three races of the [[Richmond Marathon|Anthem Richmond Marathon]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Man Behind the Scenes Profile|url=http://www.timesdispatch.com/news/ray-patterson-sports-backers-man-behind-the-scenes-on-race/article_e323943b-339d-57a9-83ad-81d56e076816.html|work=[[Richmond Times-Dispatch]]|accessdate=26 July 2014}}</ref>
==Active RVA==
The Sports Backers added a number of programs in 2012 under the shared moniker of Active RVA, a region-wide initiative to motivate area residents, businesses and local governments to make physical activity a personal and regional priority.<ref>{{cite web|title=Adding Physical Activity to the Work Place|url=http://www.timesdispatch.com/entertainment-life/health/fitness/fitness-adding-physical-activity-to-the-workplace/article_84454ceb-d1d1-5803-be04-ff624be2b324.html|work=[[Richmond Times-Dispatch]]|accessdate=26 July 2014}}</ref> The organization has started a program to certify schools and businesses that go above and beyond to increase physical activity for their students and employees.<ref>{{cite web|title=Active RVA Certification for Companies|url=http://www.activerva.org/work/active-rva-certification-fit-companies/|website=ActiveRVA.org|publisher=Active RVA}}</ref> Another program encourages the use of stairs through a stairwell signage initiative. A fitness oasis program exists to increase fitness opportunities in underserved parts of the region. The success of the Active RVA program is being measured through a combination of community indicators that has resulted in the region receiving a "C" grade for its overall fitness programs.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Riggan|first1=Phil|title=Sports Backers Grade Richmond's Fitness|url=http://www.richmond.com/recreation/article_5c49a112-9329-11e3-9105-001a4bcf6878.html|website=Richmond.com|publisher=Richmond.com}}</ref>
==Bike Walk RVA==
The Active RVA effort includes Bike Walk RVA,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Thompson|first1=Andy|title=Outdoors: New Program to Benefit Bike, Pedestrian Policies|url=http://www.timesdispatch.com/sports/columnists-blogs/andy-thompson/outdoors-new-program-to-benefit-bike-pedestrian-policies/article_e1866d5e-01ec-5750-b22a-b27d2ad06da5.html|website=timesdipsatch.com|publisher=Richmond Times-Dispatch|accessdate=27 July 2014}}</ref> a program of the Sports Backers to support bike and pedestrian friendly policies, programs and infrastructure projects. The Sports Backers work with area leaders and public works staff to fund and install bike lanes, trails and sidewalks. The strength of the program is based on 40,000 individuals from around the region that are part of the Bike Walk RVA advocacy database. These advocates send e-mails, show up at public hearings, write letters and organize support for biking and pedestrian improvements in their neighborhoods.<ref name="CBS 6 Richmond">{{cite web|title=Advocates Want to Make it Safer to Cycle|url=http://wtvr.com/2013/05/16/bike-enthusiasts-want-to-make-it-safer-to-cycle-river-city/|accessdate=26 July 2014}}</ref>
The Sports Backers measure the success of the Bike Walk RVA program by measuring the total miles of bike lanes, paved trails and dirt trails added each year. In 2012 the Sports Backers staff rode, ran or walked every mile of existing bike lanes and trails (paved and dirt) in the Richmond region. The resulting baseline report provides the starting point for the region's bike infrastructure.<ref name="Sports Backers">{{cite web|title=Bicycle Baseline Infrastructure Report|url=http://www.richmond.com/recreation/article_5c49a112-9329-11e3-9105-001a4bcf6878.html|website=Richmond.com|accessdate=26 July 2014}}</ref>
==Kids Run RVA==
Each year, thousands of area youth participate in the Sports Backers' Kids Run RVA program which includes a variety of ways to support and reward youth athletic achievement. In 2014, there were 10,000 youth that took part in the Kids Challenge running and walking incentive program at elementary schools throughout the Richmond region. Another program, the Healthy School Challenge rewarded middle and high school students for participating in the Ukrop's Monument Avenue 10k. A particular emphasis is placed on outreach to underserved schools by offering grants and support to encourage participation in specific programs.
==Scholarship program== {{third-party|date=March 2017}} The Sports Backers have been providing scholarships to area student athletes since 1992. Since the start of the scholarship program, Sports Backers have given over $660,000 to more than 395 student athletes.<ref>{{cite web|title=Scholarships|url=http://www.sportsbackers.org/scholarships/|website=Sports Backers|publisher=Sports Backers}}</ref> In 2014, the organization provided $65,000 in scholarship funds to area student athletes.<ref>{{cite web|title=Scholar-Athlete Awards Dinner|url=http://www.sportsbackers.org/other/richmond-times-dispatchsports-backers-scholar-athlete-finalists-announced/|website=Sports Backers|accessdate=27 July 2014}}</ref> The organization also provides recognition and financial awards for the top high school athletic teams and the "comeback athletes" of the year.<ref>{{cite web|title=Scholar Athletes of the Year|url=http://www.timesdispatch.com/sports/high-school/schools/james-river/roberts-and-thornhill-named-scholar-athletes-of-the-year/article_456c75a0-cc96-11e2-9d36-0019bb30f31a.html|work=[[Richmond Times-Dispatch]]|accessdate=26 July 2014}}</ref>

{{See also|Reducing emissions from deforestation and forest degradation}} {{Infobox organization | image = UN-REDD-logo.gif | alt = The UN-REDD logo | caption = | map = UN-REDD Countries.svg | map_size = | map_alt = | headquarters = [[Geneva, Switzerland]] | leader_title = Head, UN-REDD Programme Secretariat | leader_name = Mario Boccucci | parent_organization = [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] (FAO), [[United Nations Development Programme]] (UNDP), [[United Nations Environment Programme]] (UNEP) | name = United Nations Programme on Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation | native_name = | image_size = | map_caption = {{Legend|#2b3bb6|UN-REDD National Programmes}} {{Legend|#346733|UN-REDD Partner Countries}} | established = {{start date and age|2008|09|24}} | membership = 64 Partner Countries | website = {{url|http://www.un-redd.org/}} }}
The '''United Nations Programme on Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation''' (or '''UN-REDD Programme''') is a collaborative programme of the [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] of the United Nations (FAO), the [[United Nations Development Programme]] (UNDP) and the [[United Nations Environment Programme]] (UNEP), created in 2008 in response to the [[UNFCCC]] decisions on the [[Bali Action Plan]] and [[Reducing emissions from deforestation and forest degradation|REDD]] at [[2007 United Nations Climate Change Conference|COP-13]].<ref name=":0">[http://www.un-redd.org UN-REDD Programme official website.]</ref> It should not be confused with "REDD+", a voluntary climate change mitigation approach that has been developed by Parties to the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change|UNFCCC]] (see below "Difference between REDD+ and the UN-REDD Programme").
The overall development goal of the Programme is "to reduce forest emissions and enhance carbon stocks in forests while contributing to national sustainable development".<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.unredd.net/index.php?option=com_docman&view=document&alias=14096-un-redd-pb14-2015-strategic-framework&category_slug=session-3-strategic-and-policy-issues&Itemid=134|title=UN-REDD Programme 2016-2020 Strategic Framework|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
The UN-REDD Programme supports nationally led REDD+ processes and promotes the informed and meaningful involvement of all stakeholders, including indigenous peoples and other forest-dependent communities, in national and international REDD+ implementation.<ref name=":0" />
The Programme has expanded steadily since its establishment and now has over 60 official Partner Countries spanning Africa, Asia-Pacific and Latin America-Caribbean.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.unredd.net|title=UN-REDD Programme Online Collaborative Workspace|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
In addition to the UN-REDD Programme, other initiatives assisting countries that are engaged in [[Reducing emissions from deforestation and forest degradation|REDD+]] include the World Bank’s Forest Carbon Partnership Facility, Norway’s International Climate and Forest Initiative, the Global Environment Facility, Australia’s International Forest Carbon Initiative, the Collaborative Partnership on Forests, and the Green Climate Fund.
The UN-REDD Programme publicly releases each year an Annual Programme Progress Report and a Semi-Annual Report.<ref name=":2" />
== Support to Partner Countries ==
The UN-REDD Programme supports its Partner Countries through:<ref name=":0" /> * Direct funding and technical support to the design and implementation of National REDD+ Programmes; * Complementary tailored funding and technical support to national REDD+ actions; and * Technical country capacity enhancing support through sharing of expertise, common approaches, analyses, methodologies, tools, data, best practices and facilitated South-South knowledge sharing.
== Governance == The UN-REDD Programme's 2016-2020 governance arrangements allow for the full and effective participation of all UN-REDD Programme stakeholders – partner countries, donors, indigenous peoples, civil society organizations, participating UN agencies – while ensuring streamlined decision-making processes and clear lines of accountability.<ref name=":1" />
The governance arrangements are built on and informed by five principles: inclusiveness, transparency, accountability, consensus-based decisions and participation.<ref name=":1" />
UN-REDD Programme 2016-2020 governance arrangements include:
=== Executive Board ===
The [http://www.unredd.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2338&Itemid=804 UN-REDD Programme Executive Board] has general oversight for the Programme, taking decisions on the allocation of the UN-REDD Programme fund resources. It meets bi-annually, or more frequently as required to efficiently carry out its roles and responsibilities.<ref name=":1" />
=== Assembly ===
The [http://www.unredd.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2337&Itemid=803 UN-REDD Programme Assembly] is a broad multi-stakeholder forum with the role to foster consultation, dialogue and knowledge exchange among UN-REDD Programme stakeholders.<ref name=":1" />
=== National Steering Committees ===
National Steering Committees facilitate strong country ownership and shared/common decision-making for National REDD+ Programmes, and include representatives of civil society and indigenous peoples. Each National Steering Committee provides oversight for National Programmes, addressing any delays, changes or reorientation of a programme and ensuring alignment with and delivery of results as expected and approved by the Executive Board.<ref name=":1" />
=== Multi-Party Trust Fund Office ===
The [http://mptf.undp.org/factsheet/fund/CCF00 Multi-Party Trust Fund Office] provides real-time funding administration to the UN-REDD Programme.<ref name=":1" />
== 2016-2020 Strategic Framework == The work of the UN-REDD Programme is guided by its [http://www.unredd.net/index.php?option=com_docman&view=document&alias=14096-un-redd-pb14-2015-strategic-framework&category_slug=session-3-strategic-and-policy-issues&Itemid=134 2016-2020 Strategic Framework], with the goal to: Reduce forest emissions and enhance carbon stocks in forests while contributing to national sustainable development.<ref name=":1" />
In order to realize its goal and target impacts, the Programme has set three outcomes and supporting outputs for its 2016-2020 work programme:<ref name=":1" /> # Contributions of REDD+ to the mitigation of climate change as well as to the provision of additional benefits have been designed. # Country contributions to the mitigation of climate change though REDD+ are measured, reported and verified and necessary institutional arrangements are in place. # REDD+ contributions to the mitigation of climate change are implemented and safeguarded with policies and measures that constitute results-based actions, including the development of appropriate and effective institutional arrangements. Additionally, the Programme has identified four important cross-cutting themes as being particularly significant in order to ensure that the outcomes and outputs of the Programme will achieve results as desired: Stakeholder Engagement, Forest Governance, Tenure Security and Gender Equality.<ref name=":1" />
== Donors == The UN-REDD Programme depends entirely on voluntary funds. Donors to the UN-REDD Programme have included the European Commission and governments of Denmark, Japan, Luxembourg, Norway, Spain and Switzerland—with Norway providing a significant portion of the funds.<ref name=":0" />
== Transparency == The UN-REDD Programme adheres to the belief that information is fundamental to the effective participation of all stakeholders, including the public, in the advancement of REDD+ efforts around the world. Information sharing promotes transparency and accountability and enables public participation in REDD+ activities.<ref name=":0" />
The collaborating UN agencies of the UN-REDD Programme – FAO, UNEP and UNDP – are committed to making information about the Programme and its operations available to the public in the interest of transparency.<ref name=":0" /> As part of this commitment, the Programme publishes [http://www.unredd.net/index.php?option=com_docman&view=list&slug=programme-progress-reports-785&Itemid=134 annual and semi-annual programme progress reports] and provides [http://mptf.undp.org/factsheet/fund/CCF00 online public access to real-time funding administration].<ref name=":0" />
== Difference between REDD+ and the UN-REDD Programme == [[Reducing emissions from deforestation and forest degradation|REDD+]] is a voluntary climate change mitigation approach that has been developed by Parties to the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change|UNFCCC]]. It aims to incentivize developing countries to reduce emissions from deforestation and [[forest degradation]], conserve forest carbon stocks, sustainably manage forests and enhance forest carbon stocks.
The United Nations Collaborative Programme on Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation in Developing Countries – or UN-REDD Programme – is a multilateral body. It partners with developing countries to support them in establishing the technical capacities needed to implement REDD+ and meet UNFCCC requirements for REDD+ results-based payments. It does so through a country-based approach that provides advisory and technical support services tailored to national circumstances and needs. The UN-REDD Programme is a collaborative programme of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP), and harnesses the technical expertise of these UN agencies. Other examples of REDD+ multilaterals include the Forest Carbon Partnership Facility and Forest Investment Program, hosted by The World Bank.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unredd.net/index.php?option=com_docman&view=document&alias=15279-fact-sheet-about-redd&category_slug=fact-sheets&Itemid=134|title=Fact Sheet: About REDD+|last=|first=|date=February 2016|website=|publisher=UN-REDD Programme|access-date=}}</ref>
== See also ==

{{About|the Pope and the Holy Roman Emperor in the Middle Ages|the idea of subtle fields of energy surrounding any living thing|Energy (esotericism)}}
[[Image:Nuremberg Chronicles - Aeneas, Pope and Frederick 3rd, Emperor (CCLXVIIv).jpg|thumb|The pope [[Pius II]] and the emperor [[Frederick III, Holy Roman Emperor|Frederick III]].]] [[Image:Otto I begegnet Papst Johannes XII.jpg|thumb|[[Pope John XII]] and emperor [[Otto I]].]] [[Image:Clement III - Antipope.jpg|thumb|Antipope [[Clement III]] and emperor [[Henry IV, Holy Roman Emperor|Henry IV]].]]
In the [[Middle Ages]], the term '''universal powers''' referred to the [[Holy Roman Emperor]] and the [[Pope]]. Both were struggling for the so-called ''[[Dominium mundi]]'', or world dominium, in terms of political and spiritual supremacy. The emperor and the pope maintained their respective authorities through diverse factors such as territorial dispersion, low level of technic{{clarify|date=September 2010|reason="technic" singular is not a word, certainly not a common word}} and productive development in feudal [[mode of production]], and social and political tendency of [[feudalism]] to [[decentralization]] of [[political power|power]].
The universal powers continued into the early 19th century until the [[Napoleonic Wars]]. The reshaping of Europe meant the effective end of the Empire. Although the Papacy had its territorial limits confined to the [[Vatican City|Vatican]], it retained its [[soft power]] in the contemporary world.
==Origins== {{Main|Dominium mundi}} Given the [[Caesaropapism]]{{Technical-statement|date=July 2011}} of the [[Byzantine Empire]], the situation in the [[Western World]] after the [[decline of the Roman Empire]] assumed an exceptionally powerful position of the [[Bishop of Rome]]. As the only [[patriarch]] in the Western World, his status was soon converted into that of a [[primate (bishop)]]. In addition to this spiritual power, the Bishop of Rome sought to gain [[Temporal power (Papal)|temporal power]] over a territory held by various Germanic Kingdoms in order to make it a true [[theocracy]]. The Bishop of Rome tried to extend his territory from the city of [[Rome]] to the whole of [[Italy]] and further to the whole of the [[Western Roman Empire]] (in accordance with the [[Donation of Constantine]]). The coronation of [[Charlemagne]] in the year 800, which began the [[Carolingian Empire]], marked the appearance of a secular authority with universal claims. The two century long coexistence of the Pontiff and the Empire (regnum et sacerdocium) was difficult and yielded the [[Investiture Controversy]] and several different ideological formulations (the theory of the [[Divine Right of Kings|two swords]], Plenitutdo postestatis, ''[[Dictatus papae]]'', condemnations of [[simony]], and [[nicolaism]]). In these the Pope tried to establish the supremacy of [[religious authority]] over [[civil authority]]. Meanwhile, the Emperor tried to enforce the [[Legitimacy (political)|legitimacy]] of his position, which claimed to come from the old Roman Empire (''[[Translatio imperii]]''). In order to do this, he established his military capability to impose his territorial power and extend his power over religious life. This was done in a manner similar to that of his equivalent in the East. Both efforts fell far short of their goals.<ref>[[Julio Valdeón Baruque]] y [[José Ángel García de Cortázar]], in FERNÁNDEZ ÁLVAREZ, Manuel; AVILÉS FERNÁNDEZ, Miguel y ESPADAS BURGOS, Manuel (dirs.) (1986), Gran Historia Universal (volúmenes 11 y 12), Barcelona, Club Internacional del Libro. {{ISBN|84-7461-654-9}}. Especially Julio Valdeón: ''La época de las ideas universales. El pontificado y el imperio. Las criuzadas. Capetos y Angevinos'', pp. 131–157.</ref>
==Evolution== The division of the Carolingian Empire between the heirs of [[Louis the Pious]] and the claims of different dynasties, such as the [[Ottonian dynasty|Ottonian]] and the [[House of Hohenstaufen]], to the imperial title, debilitated the power of the emperors and subjected them to a system of election. The system of election made them dependent on a delicate game of alliances between the nobles that held the title of [[Prince-Elector]], some laymen and others clergymen. Notwithstanding, he would periodically try to regain imperial power ([[Otto III, Holy Roman Emperor|Otto III]], [[Henry II, Holy Roman Emperor|Henry II]]). At times this led to spectacular confrontations ([[Henry IV, Holy Roman Emperor|Henry IV]], [[Frederick I, Holy Roman Emperor|Frederick I Barbarossa]], [[Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor|Frederick II]]). The strengthening of the power of the papacy was very important from Pope [[Pope Gregory I|Gregory I]] on, and depended on the support of the monastic orders, above all the [[Cluny Abbey|Order of Cluny]]. The constitution of many of these new kingdoms made them feudally obligated to the Pope, which liberated them from the theoretical feudal subjugation of the emperor or another king (such was the case of [[Portugal]]). In the territory of the Sacred Empire, the rivalry between the [[Guelphs]], supporting the Papacy, and [[Ghibellines]], supporting the Emperor, dominated [[Germany|German]] and [[Italy|Italian]] political life from the 12th to the 15th century.
Eventually, the authority of the Emperor was converted into something purely theoretical, lacking a strong economic or military base. He was incapable of not only standing up to the [[feudal monarchies]] definitively free of all subordination ''Rex superiorem non recognoscens in regno suo est Imperator'' (Decretal Per Venerabilem by [[Pope Innocent III|Innocent III]], 1202),<ref>[[Francisco Tomás y Valiente]] et al. (1996) [''Autonomía y soberanía. Una consideración histórica''], Madrid: Marcial Pons; cited in ''Revista de estudios histórico-jurídicos'' nº 21, Valparaíso 1999 {{ISSN|0716-5455}} [http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:FmOL-1KaGtsJ:www.scielo.cl/scielo.php%3Fpid%3DS0716-54551999002100056%26script%3Dsci_arttext+rex+est+imperator+in+regno+suo&hl=es&ct=clnk&cd=1&gl=es]</ref> but to his own territorial princes or Italian city-states. The papal authority also decayed. The [[Crusades]], advocated by the pope, did not give him more control of the briefly conquered territories in the [[Holy Land]], the European kingdoms, or of the new [[religious orders]]. With the [[Avignon Papacy]] and the [[Western Schism]], the French Monarchy subjugated the Papacy to its control. This further weakened the Pope's power and undermined the intimidating power of [[excommunication]], which had been greatly feared.<ref>Julio Valdeón, ''op. cit.'', ''El siglo XIII. El fin de las construcciones universales. El auge de las monarquías nacionales'', vol. 12 pp. 161–184.</ref>
The production of theoretical arguments on the theme of universal power, on the other hand, continued and included contributions such as those of [[Marsilius of Padua]], ''Defensor Pacis'' or [[William of Ockham]], ''Eight Questions about the Authority of the Pope'' (1342) and ''De imperatorum et pontificum potestate'' (1347).<ref>[http://www.dykinson.com/book--Sobre_el_poder_de_los_emperadores_y_los_papas--21160.2.7..1.html Bibliographic review] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110710160611/http://www.dykinson.com/book--Sobre_el_poder_de_los_emperadores_y_los_papas--21160.2.7..1.html |date=2011-07-10 }} of this.</ref> Such works continued to undermine the universal ambitions of both authorities and were produced by the most important authors of the scholasticism crisis. The scholasticism crisis debated the adoption and extension of new legal ideas taken from [[Roman Law]], with the ''[[jus commune]]'' of the School of Bologna on one side and [[conciliarism]] of the Counsel of Florence on the other.
==End== [[Image:Sebastiano Ricci 035.jpg|thumb|The emperor [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles V]] was reconciled with the king [[Francis I of France]] both encouraged by pope [[Paul III]], oil by [[Sebastiano Ricci]].]]
Both universal powers entered the [[Modern Age]] very debilitated, although their power continued to be notable. They tried to recoup what was lost. These attempts, however, proved unsuccessful, as in the cases of the emperor [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles V]]<ref>The imperial idea of Charles V, at times characterized as a universal monarchy, had been subject to many different interpretations about its modernity or medievality<!--WORD?-->. His advisors, the Italian chancellor Murcurino Gattinara, his Flemish preceptor [[Adrian of Utrecht]] (future Pope Adrian VI) and the Castilians doctor Mota and monk [[Antonio de Guevara]]. ([http://www.caballerosdeyuste.es/estudios/lengua/lengua.htm ''Carlos V y la lengua española''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080510121659/http://www.caballerosdeyuste.es/estudios/lengua/lengua.htm |date=2008-05-10 }} by [[Manuel Alvar]] extracted from: ''Nebrija y estudios sobre la Edad de Oro''. Madrid: C.S.I.C., 1997, pp. 169–188; which collects and briefly comments on the bibliography of the debate). Other references: [http://dialnet.unirioja.es/servlet/articulo?codigo=603778 File of the article] by [[Joseph Pérez]]. [http://tanger.cervantes.es/Biblioteca/Fichas/Men%C3%A9ndez%20Pidal,%20Ram%C3%B3n,%201869-1968_25082_35_1.shtml File of the classic work] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080511052213/http://tanger.cervantes.es/Biblioteca/Fichas/Men%C3%A9ndez%20Pidal,%20Ram%C3%B3n,%201869-1968_25082_35_1.shtml |date=2008-05-11 }} by [[Ramón Menéndez Pidal]] (1937), response from an “hispanisist” perspective to the German [[Karl Brandi|Karl Brandi’s]] book, ''Carlos V. Vida y fortuna de una personalidad y de un Imperio mundial'' ([http://www.cervantesvirtual.com/historia/CarlosV/fondos_documentales.shtml Notes over the documentary and bibliographic resources about Charles V] by Claudia Möller, in cervantesvirtual). [http://www.kalipedia.com/historia-espanola/tema/edad-moderna/proyecto-imperio-cristiano.html?x=20070712klphishes_130.Kes&ap=0 A very brief reference on the subject] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080511033211/http://www.kalipedia.com/historia-espanola/tema/edad-moderna/proyecto-imperio-cristiano.html?x=20070712klphishes_130.Kes&ap=0 |date=2008-05-11 }} in Kalipedia.</ref> and the pontiffs of the [[Renaissance]] ([[Alexander VI]] and [[Julius II]]) and the [[Counter-Reformation]], whose ambitions proved impossible in the long term. The reality that was imposed during the [[Ancien Régime]] was that of new authoritarian monarchies (such as the [[Catholic Monarchs|Catholic Monarchy]]) that evolved towards [[Absolute monarchy|absolutism]] (as in [[France]]) or towards the bourgeois revolutions (as in [[the Netherlands]] with the [[Dutch Revolt]] and in [[England]] with the [[English Civil War]]). In 1648 the [[Treaty of Westphalia]] definitively supplanted the role of the universal powers and brought about modern, [[Secularization|secularized]] [[international relations]] based on [[pragmatism]] and the prominence of [[Sovereign state|states]].<ref>[http://www.argentina-rree.com/2/2-002.htm ''La evolución del sistema interestatal desde la Paz de Westfalia hasta la Revolución Francesa, vista desde una perspectiva analítica'' (The evolution of the interstatal system from the Peace of Westphalia until the French Revolution, view from an analytic perspective), that cites as a source Rosecrance, The Rise of the Trading State. Commerce and Conquest in the Modern World, New York, Basic Books, 1986.]</ref> Even within Catholic countries, the theory that only monarchs could grant [[royalties]] effectively limited the pontifical power.
The 19th century was the end of both universal powers as territorial entities: the Sacro Imperio was formally abolished by [[Napoleon Bonaparte]], who created his own empire, and although Napoleon's empire was defeated, the Holy Roman Empire was not restored in the redrawing of the European map following the [[Congress of Vienna]] (1814–1815). The territories recuperated by the [[Habsburg dynasty]] were transformed into a multinational state, first as the [[Austrian Empire]] and later as a dual monarchy, the [[Austro-Hungarian Empire]], which lasted until 1918. Additionally, the leadership of [[Prussia]] in the recently created [[German Confederation]] brought about the constitution of the [[Second German Empire]] in 1871.<ref>{{cite book | last = HOBSBAWM | first = Eric J. | title = Las Revoluciones Burguesas (The Age of Revolution. Europe 1789–1848) | year = 1987 | publisher = Barcelona: Labor | isbn = 84-335-2978-1 }} </ref>
Simultaneously, the relations of the Pope with the [[French Revolution]] and Napoleon, as with ideological [[liberalism]] itself, oscillated between direct opposition and forced coexistence. In 1860, the new [[Kingdom of Italy (1861–1946)|Kingdom of Italy]], formed by the [[Kingdom of Piedmont-Sardinia]], conquered the [[Papal States|Papal States']] territorial base (called [[Marche]]) in the center of Italy. The Kingdom of Italy did not take Rome itself, however, until 1871 when the [[Second French Empire]] of [[Napoleon III]] withdrew its garrison in Rome which had served to protect the Papal States. The Pope's rejection of the situation and the voluntary confinement of the popes in the Vatican continued until the [[Lateran Pacts]] of 1929 with the Italian [[fascist]] [[Benito Mussolini]].<ref>{{cite book | last = HOBSBAWM | first = Eric J. | title = La Era del capitalismo (The Age of Capital 1848–1875) | year = 1987 | publisher = Barcelona: Labor | isbn = 84-335-2983-8 }} </ref>
Since then, the efforts of the Pope in the international scene and in the internal business of Catholic countries have transcended the territorial dimensions of the Vatican City, demonstrating that the religious dimension is very decisive. It has also shown that what has come to be called [[soft power]], though subtle, can be effective because of its moral, ideological, and cultural weight. [[File:NapoleanCoronationDavid.jpg|thumb|center|650px|Coronation of Napoleon and Josefina before the Pope, reduced to an observer role, oil by [[Jacques-Louis David]].]]
==Perseverance of the term== The name of "[[empire]]" has been applied to types of political entities that have not had a universal function (theocratic or Caesaropapist), but to those with a global, secularized one. This has been possible in [[Geostrategy|geostrategic]] terms for the first time since the coming about of a [[global economy]].<ref>Concepto de [[Fernand Braudel]] {{cite book | last = BRAUDEL | first = Fernand | title = Civilización material, economía y capitalismo, siglos XV–XVIII | year = 1984 | publisher = Madrid, Alianza | isbn = 84-206-9024-4 }} desarrollado por [[Immanuel Wallerstein]] {{cite book | last = WALLERSTEIN | first = Immanuel | title = El moderno sistema mundial La agricultura capitalista y los orígenes de la economía-mundo europea en el siglo XVI | year = 1979 | publisher = Madrid, Siglo XXI | isbn = 84-323-0342-9 }} </ref> Although the first empires to form (the [[Portuguese Empire]] and [[Spanish Empire]] in the 16th century) in their day did not refer to themselves as empires, (the Spanish self defined, in [[Providentialism|providentialist]] terms, as the Catholic Monarchy), the name typically has been applied by [[historiography]] (which applies "empire" to any political form of the past with multinational dimensions: [[Göktürks|Turk Empire]], [[Mongol Empire]], [[Inca Empire]]).
Consequently, this is done to the [[Russian Empire]], which claimed to be a [[New Rome|third Rome]] after the [[fall of Constantinople]] in 1453 (the title [[Czar]] is derived from [[Caesar (title)|Caesar]]).
The term is also applied to the overseas territorial possessions of the European states: *the [[British Empire]] – justified by the Hindu [[:wikt:raj|Raj]] who made [[Queen Victoria]] empress of India *the [[France|French Empire]] – that of the first Napoleon and that of the Third, although the name continued to be used for the colonies of the Third Republic *the [[Italian Empire]] – that Mussolini sought in Africa
Analogously, the name "empire" is also used to refer to non-European entities, such as the [[History of China|Chinese Empire]] and the [[Japanese Empire]], or give the title of emperor to those like the [[Negus]] of [[Ethiopia]], the [[Shah]] of [[Persia]], and the [[Sultan]] of [[Morocco]].<ref>{{cite book | last = HOBSBAWM | first = Eric J. | title = La Era del Imperio (The Age of Empire 1875–1914) | year = 1989 | publisher = Barcelona: Labor | isbn = 84-335-9298-X }} pp. 56–57 </ref> In most cases, this is a "diplomatic courtesy." Since the [[Cold War]], it has also been common to refer to the two rival superpowers as the American Empire and the Soviet Empire.
==See also== * [[Cesaropapism]] * [[Guelphs and Ghibellines]] * [[Investiture Controversy]] * [[Theocracy]] * ''[[Dictatus papae]]'' * ''[[Translatio imperii]]''

Mitchell, ([[Chairman (official)|Chairman]])
Martha P. Heath (Vice-Chair) | area_served = [[Vermont]] | product = [[Student financial aid (United States)|Student financial aid]] | focus = | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = 254 | num_members = | subsib = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = | homepage = [http://www.vsac.org www.vsac.org] | dissolved = | footnotes = }} The '''Vermont Student Assistance Corporation''' ('''VSAC''') is a [[Non-profit organization|nonprofit]] [[Government-owned corporation|public corporation]] that was created by the [[Government of Vermont|State of Vermont]] in 1965 to provide citizens of the state with the information and financial resources they need to pursue education or training beyond high school. VSAC provides "one-stop" delivery of higher education services including: career, college, and financial aid information and counseling, state grants for full-time, part-time, and non-degree study, administration of, or information about, dozens of scholarships available to Vermonters, low-interest private loans for students and parents, and the Vermont Higher Education Investment Plan.{{cite news|url=http://www.vermontguides.com/1998/profil46.htm|title=VSAC Helps Students to Various Degrees|first=Craig C|last=Bailey|work=Business Digest|publisher=Vermont Guide|year=1998|accessdate=2008-04-21}} VSAC administers a summer employment program for eligible students and provides financial aid services for 10 Vermont [[Higher education|post-secondary institutions]]. VSAC employs 350 people{{cite news | first=Tim | last=Johnson | title=VSAC celebrates outreach programs | url=| work= | publisher=Burlington Free Press | location=Burlington, Vermont | pages= 1B | date=6 October 2009 | id= | accessdate=}} and is governed by an 11-member Board of Directors. Five of the members are appointed by the [[Governor of Vermont|Governor]], two are legislative members, one is the State Treasurer, and the remaining three are chosen by the Board itself.{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}} The Vermont appropriations for fiscal year 2009 contains $19,153,758 for VSAC.[http://www.leg.state.vt.us/jfo/Appropriations/235883-v1-FY2009_APPROPRIATIONS.XLS 2009 Vermont appropriations]{{dead link|date=July 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} retrieved July 21, 2008 ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.vsac.org/ VSAC Website] [[Category:Winooski, Vermont]] [[Category:Government of Vermont|Student]] [[Category:Government corporations]] {{Vermont-stub}}
